text:
“My friend, she is volunteering
for the hospitals.

She sent me a huge list,
but I wasn’t
able to buy much in Poland.

So first-aid kit,
and here’s some food.

The lighters, they asked me to
bring some cookies, painkillers,

instant soups, power banks
and some materials
just to make bandages.

They are even out
of the bandages.
Yeah, so.

You see,
the bag is huge.

I still have space,
but it’s basically whatever
I could get yesterday.”

“I’m surprised how many people
want to get back to Ukraine,

and to be honest,
I’m surprised to see
a lot of women here.
As I suggested,

I will see only men
as it’s expected.

They’re defenders,
first of all, but so many women,
it’s like, whoa.
Me and my husband

were on vacation in Egypt,
and we get breakfast and get
to lobby to connect to Wi-Fi.

And my husband
just read the news
and was like, ‘Honey,
the war started.’
So we bought tickets to Berlin.
From Berlin,

we traveled to Poland,
stayed for a few days
at our relatives’ in Warsaw.

And now we are here,
and getting back.

In Kyiv, we have left my
parents, mother, father
and my smaller sister,
our pets.

To be honest, I’m not scared
now to get back there.
I’m just furious.”
“So I’m coming from Oman.
I arrived yesterday to Poland.

My mom lives in Kharkiv,
and I’m trying to get her out.

And as well, I’m doing
some humanitarian delivery.

She doesn’t want
to go with people

that she doesn’t know
because now she just
like so scared of everything.

It’s constant bombing,
especially the living areas.

It’s actually quite critical
because she has problem —

heart issues,
and her medical supply

is like for maybe
10 to 15 days more.

I’m feeling now that I’m
at least helping and doing

something, so hopefully I will
be able to reach her in Kharkiv,
and pick her up.”

“I just arrived from the U.K.
on the plane to Poland
to collect my mother.

We warned, we forecasted, and my
mom always said, ‘Don’t panic.
Everything will be great.

He has no idea what
Ukraine is like.
He will never go for Ukraine.’

So I said, ‘Mom,
no, there’s lots
of tanks around the border.’

Many people I know
are in complete denial.

You wouldn’t imagine
anything like this

in the 21st century,
would you?
The city’s blown up.

I watched children
being killed.

I’ve seen so much
horror in my country.

Even if it takes my
life and my children
will be without mom,
I must save my mom.
But my brother

is going to stay because he
obviously will stay to fight.
He’s 57.
He’s my only brother.

I can’t wait to
give him a hug.”
